1: <sup>1</sup> Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,
2: <sup>2</sup> Can a man be profitable unto God, as he that is wise may be profitable unto himself?
3: <sup>3</sup> Is it any pleasure to the Almighty, that thou art righteous? or is it gain to him, that thou makest thy ways perfect?
4: <sup>4</sup> Will he reprove thee for fear of thee? will he enter with thee into judgment?
5: <sup>5</sup> Is not thy wickedness great? and thine iniquities infinite?
6: <sup>6</sup> For thou hast taken a pledge from thy brother for nought, and stripped the naked of their clothing.
7: <sup>7</sup> Thou hast not given water to the weary to drink, and thou hast withholden bread from the hungry.
8: <sup>8</sup> But as for the mighty man, he had the earth; and the honourable man dwelt in it.
9: <sup>9</sup> Thou hast sent widows away empty, and the arms of the fatherless have been broken.
10: <sup>10</sup> Therefore snares are round about thee, and sudden fear troubleth thee;
11: <sup>11</sup> Or darkness, that thou canst not see; and abundance of waters cover thee.
12: <sup>12</sup> Is not God in the height of heaven? and behold the height of the stars, how high they are!
13: <sup>13</sup> And thou sayest, How doth God know? can he judge through the dark cloud?
14: <sup>14</sup> Thick clouds are a covering to him, that he seeth not; and he walketh in the circuit of heaven.
15: <sup>15</sup> Hast thou marked the old way which wicked men have trodden?
16: <sup>16</sup> Which were cut down out of time, whose foundation was overflown with a flood:
17: <sup>17</sup> Which said unto God, Depart from us: and what can the Almighty do for them?
18: <sup>18</sup> Yet he filled their houses with good things: but the counsel of the wicked is far from me.
19: <sup>19</sup> The righteous see it, and are glad: and the innocent laugh them to scorn.
20: <sup>20</sup> Whereas our substance is not cut down, but the remnant of them the fire consumeth.
21: <sup>21</sup> Acquaint now thyself with him, and be at peace: thereby good shall come unto thee.
22: <sup>22</sup> Receive, I pray thee, the law from his mouth, and lay up his words in thine heart.
23: <sup>23</sup> If thou return to the Almighty, thou shalt be built up, thou shalt put away iniquity far from thy tabernacles.
24: <sup>24</sup> Then shalt thou lay up gold as dust, and the gold of Ophir as the stones of the brooks.
25: <sup>25</sup> Yea, the Almighty shall be thy defence, and thou shalt have plenty of silver.
26: <sup>26</sup> For then shalt thou have thy delight in the Almighty, and shalt lift up thy face unto God.
27: <sup>27</sup> Thou shalt make thy prayer unto him, and he shall hear thee, and thou shalt pay thy vows.
28: <sup>28</sup> Thou shalt also decree a thing, and it shall be established unto thee: and the light shall shine upon thy ways.
29: <sup>29</sup> When men are cast down, then thou shalt say, There is lifting up; and he shall save the humble person.
30: <sup>30</sup> He shall deliver the island of the innocent: and it is delivered by the pureness of thine hands.
